questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with pain in her left thigh for 3 months. She also complains of intermittent fever. On examination there is a swelling in the mid shaft of femur. The x ray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ewing's sarcoma is a malignant bone tumor typically affecting children and adolescents, often presenting with pain, swelling, and systemic symptoms like fever. It commonly involves the diaphysis (shaft) of long bones, such as the femur. The X-ray shows a characteristic "onion-skin" periosteal reaction, which is typical of Ewing's sarcoma. This radiologic appearance helps differentiate it from osteosarcoma (metaphyseal), giant cell tumor (epiphyseal), and chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with back pain after lifting a heavy stone at a construction site. His MRI shows intervertebral disc prolapse at L4-L5 level. Which nerve root is most commonly affected in this condition?
questions.solution: In a lumbar disc herniation, the nerve root affected is typically the one that exits below the level of herniation. At the L4-L5 level, the L5 nerve root is most commonly compressed because the L4 nerve exits above the disc and is usually spared. Compression of L5 can cause pain radiating down the leg, weakness in foot dorsiflexion, and difficulty in toe extension.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady presents with fracture neck of femur after a fall. There is no history of osteoarthritis of the hip. Which is the ideal treatment for this lady?
questions.solution: In elderly patients with a fracture of the neck of femur, blood supply to the femoral head is often compromised, increasing the risk of avascular necrosis and non-union. Therefore, hemiarthroplasty (replacement of the femoral head) is the preferred treatment as it allows early mobilization and reduces complications. Total hip replacement is considered if there is pre-existing arthritis, which is absent in this case. Hip spica and skin traction are not definitive treatments for this age group.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in his both hands. O/E there is arthritic changes in the distal interphalangeal joints of hands. He gives a history of skin lesions for which he has been taking treatment for the last 2 years. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory joint disease associated with psoriasis, often affecting the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints, which are typically spared in rheumatoid arthritis. The presence of chronic skin lesions and DIP joint involvement strongly supports this diagnosis. Patients may also show features like dactylitis ("sausage digits") and nail changes. Other options like Reiter's syndrome and pemphigus do not typically involve DIP joints or have chronic psoriasis-like skin lesions.

choices.text: Nonunion of lateral condyle of humerus fracture

questions.text: Which injury can cause the deformity shown in the image below?
questions.solution: The deformity shown in the image is cubitus varus, commonly referred to as the "gunstock deformity." Cubitus varus is a medial angulation of the elbow that occurs most often due to a malunited supracondylar fracture of the humerus in children. Improper alignment during healing leads to the arm deviating inward when extended. This is not typically seen with Monteggia, Galeazzi, or lateral condyle fractures. While primarily a cosmetic issue, it can affect elbow mechanics over time.

questions.text: A fracture at which of the following sites of the humerus can result in Wrist drop?
questions.solution: Wrist drop is caused by injury to the radial nerve, which runs in the radial (spiral) groove located at the midshaft of the humerus -indicated by Site B in the image. A fracture at this location can damage the radial nerve, leading to paralysis of the wrist and finger extensors, resulting in the characteristic wrist drop.

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presented to the OPD with complaints of polyarthralgia for 10 years. She has developed deformities of hands over the last 2 years, which is shown in the below image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: The image shows characteristic hand deformities of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), such as ulnar deviation, swan neck deformities, and boutonnière deformities. RA is a chronic autoimmune disease that typically affects small joints symmetrically, especially the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. The patient's long history of polyarthralgia and progressive deformities is highly suggestive of RA.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains injury to his right knee after a road traffic accident. His x ray is given below. What is the treatment of choice in this situation?
questions.solution: The X-ray shows a fracture of the patella, a common injury from direct trauma to the knee, such as in road traffic accidents. In displaced transverse patellar fractures, tension band wiring (TBW) is the treatment of choice. TBW converts the tensile forces on the anterior surface of the patella into compressive forces at the fracture site, promoting healing. It preserves the extensor mechanism and allows early mobilization.

questions.text: Identify the Instrument?
questions.solution: The instrument shown is a Bohler Braun splint, which is used for immobilization and traction in lower limb fractures, especially femur and tibia fractures. It provides a frame for applying skeletal or skin traction, helping in fracture alignment and pain relief. The vertical bars and pulley system allow for controlled, multidirectional traction. It's commonly used in orthopedic wards before definitive surgical treatment.

questions.text: In which nerve injury is the splint shown in the image used?
questions.solution: The splint shown in the image is a dynamic cock-up splint, which is used in radial nerve palsy. Radial nerve injury causes wrist drop, where the patient cannot extend the wrist and fingers. This splint maintains wrist extension and supports finger extension using springs, allowing functional hand use during recovery. It prevents contractures and assists in daily activities until nerve function returns.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
PIN (Posterior Interosseous Nerve) - causes finger drop due to extensor muscle paralysis → A2

  • AIN (Anterior Interosseous Nerve) - injury shows Kiloh Nevin sign (inability to make "OK" sign) → B1
  • Ulnar Nerve - injury results in Froment’s sign (compensatory thumb flexion during pinch) → C4
  • Median Nerve - damage leads to Benediction sign (inability to flex index and middle finger when making a fist) → D3

choices.text: There is proximal migration of midpoint of body
50 % of patients have impaired sexual development

questions.text: Not true about achondroplasia.
questions.solution: Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the FGFR3 gene, leading to abnormal cartilage formation and dwarfism. Characteristic features include rhizomelic shortening (proximal limb shortening), starfish-shaped hands, and a normal trunk length with proximal migration of the body midpoint. Sexual development is typically normal, so option B is not true and is the correct answer. Intelligence is also generally unaffected.

questions.text: Which is not a part of McCune Albright syndrome?
questions.solution: McCune-Albright syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the GNAS gene. It is characterized by a classic triad: polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, café au lait spots with irregular borders ("coast of Maine" appearance), and precocious puberty (especially in girls). Multiple enchondromas are not a feature of this syndrome-they are seen in Ollier disease, making option D the correct answer.

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
• A. Osteoid osteoma → 2. Radiofrequency ablation: Minimally invasive and effective for this small, painful lesion.
  • B. GCT (Giant Cell Tumor) → 3. Extended curettage: Aggressive benign tumor often treated by curettage with adjuvants.
  • C. SBC (Simple Bone Cyst) → 4. Steroid injection: Non-operative treatment that promotes cyst resolution.
  • D. Enchondroma → 1. Simple curettage: Usually asymptomatic; curettage is done if symptomatic or enlarging.

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.text: An 18-year-old male, who has been on long term steroids for bronchial asthma, presented with pain of the right hip for the last 6 months. O/E, there is restriction of rotations of the hip joint. X ray shows crescent sign. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The crescent sign on X-ray is a classic feature of avascular necrosis (AVN) of the femoral head, indicating subchondral fracture. AVN commonly occurs due to compromised blood supply, often associated with long-term steroid use, as seen in this patient. It presents with gradual onset hip pain and restricted movement, especially internal rotation. Other options like osteoarthritis or femoroacetabular impingement are less likely in a young patient with this history and radiological finding.

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image
questions.solution: The angle shown in the image is Cobb's angle, which is used to measure the degree of scoliosis. It is calculated by drawing lines parallel to the upper endplate of the most tilted vertebra above the curve and the lower endplate of the most tilted vertebra below the curve. The angle formed where perpendiculars to these lines intersect represents the severity of spinal curvature. Cobb’s angle is a key parameter in diagnosing and monitoring scoliosis progression.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted 2 days back in your hospital after sustaining a fracture shaft of femur from an RTA. He was planned for surgery today. However, he suddenly developed, tachycardia, tachypnea, altered behavior and rashes in the periumbilical area. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution: The most likely diagnosis is Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES), which commonly occurs after long bone fractures like the femur. It typically presents 24-72 hours post-injury with a triad of symptoms: respiratory distress (tachypnea, hypoxia), neurological signs (confusion, altered behavior), and petechial rash, often seen in the periumbilical area, conjunctiva, or axilla. FES results from fat globules entering the bloodstream and lodging in pulmonary and cerebral microcirculation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with paraesthesia of right upper limb for 3 months. The test shown in the image is positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: The image shows Phalen's test, where the patient flexes both wrists and presses the backs of the hands together for 60 seconds. A positive Phalen's test elicits tingling or numbness in the distribution of the median nerve-thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger. This is characteristic of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome, which is caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

questions.text: Which organism causes osteomyelitis in a patient with sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution: In patients with sickle cell anemia, the most common cause of osteomyelitis is Salmonella species, unlike the general population where Staphylococcus aureus is more common. The sickled red cells cause vascular occlusion and bone infarction, predisposing bones to infection. Salmonella has a unique affinity for infarcted bone tissue in these patients, making it the most frequent pathogen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with chronic back pain that has progressively worsened over the past few months. He also reports fever, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. On examination, there is localized tenderness over the lower thoracic and lumbar spine. MRI spine is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The clinical features of chronic back pain, fever, night sweats, and weight loss, along with MRI showing destruction of adjacent vertebral bodies and intervertebral disc involvement, are characteristic of Pott's spine (spinal tuberculosis). The image also shows a paravertebral abscess, which supports the diagnosis. This condition is commonly seen in endemic areas and results from hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
